section.title: Verify operation
section.para: Verify operation of the Identity service before installing other services.

step.para: For security reasons, disable the temporary authentication token mechanism:
Edit the /etc/keystone/keystone-paste.ini file and remove admin_token_auth from the [pipeline:public_api], [pipeline:admin_api], and [pipeline:api_v3] sections.
Unset the temporary OS_TOKEN and OS_URL environment variables:
As the admin user, request an authentication token from the Identity version 2.0 API:

screen.userinput: openstack --os-auth-url http://controller:35357 \ --os-project-name admin --os-username admin --os-auth-type password \ token issue

note.para: This command uses the password for the admin user.

step.para: The Identity version 3 API adds support for domains that contain projects and users. Projects and users can use the same names in different domains. Therefore, in order to use the version 3 API, requests must also explicitly contain at least the default domain or use IDs. For simplicity, this guide explicitly uses the default domain so examples can use names instead of IDs.

screen.userinput: openstack --os-auth-url http://controller:35357 \ --os-project-domain-id default --os-user-domain-id default \ --os-project-name admin --os-username admin --os-auth-type password \ token issue

note.para: This command uses the password for the admin user.

step.para: As the admin user, list projects to verify that the admin user can execute admin-only CLI commands and that the Identity service contains the projects that you created in :
As the admin user, list projects to verify that the admin user can execute CLI commands and that the Identity service contains the projects created by the configuration tool:

screen.userinput: openstack --os-auth-url http://controller:35357 \ --os-project-name admin --os-username admin --os-auth-type password \ project list

note.para: This command uses the password for the admin user.

step.para: As the admin user, list users to verify that the Identity service contains the users that you created in :
As the admin user, list users to verify that the Identity service contains the users created by the configuration tool:

screen.userinput: openstack --os-auth-url http://controller:35357 \ --os-project-name admin --os-username admin --os-auth-type password \ user list

note.para: This command uses the password for the admin user.

step.para: As the admin user, list roles to verify that the Identity service contains the role that you created in :
As the admin user, list roles to verify that the Identity service contains the role created by the configuration tool:

screen.userinput: openstack --os-auth-url http://controller:35357 \ --os-project-name admin --os-username admin --os-auth-type password \ role list

note.para: This command uses the password for the admin user.

step.para: As the demo user, request an authentication token from the Identity version 3 API:

screen.userinput: openstack --os-auth-url http://controller:5000 \ --os-project-domain-id default --os-user-domain-id default \ --os-project-name demo --os-username demo --os-auth-type password \ token issue

note.para: This command uses the password for the demo user and API port 5000 which only allows regular (non-admin) access to the Identity service API.

step.para: As the demo user, attempt to list users to verify that it cannot execute admin-only CLI commands:

screen.userinput: openstack --os-auth-url http://controller:5000 \ --os-project-domain-id default --os-user-domain-id default \ --os-project-name demo --os-username demo --os-auth-type password \ user list
screen.computeroutput: ERROR: openstack You are not authorized to perform the requested action, admin_required. (HTTP 403)
